title: Saul's Rejection
shortSummary: In 1 Samuel 15, God commands King Saul through the prophet Samuel to utterly destroy the Amalekites as judgment for their past sins against Israel. Saul disobeys by sparing King Agag and the best livestock, leading to God's rejection of Saul as king. This chapter highlights the critical importance of obedience to God's commands over ritual sacrifices.
timeline: c. 1050 BC - Early Monarchy Period in Israel

keyCharacters.name: Saul
keyCharacters.description: The first king of Israel who receives a direct command from God but disobeys, leading to his rejection as king.

keyCharacters.name: Samuel
keyCharacters.description: The prophet who anoints Saul as king and confronts him over his disobedience, ultimately declaring God's judgment.

keyCharacters.name: Agag
keyCharacters.description: The king of the Amalekites who is spared by Saul but later executed by Samuel as a symbol of God's judgment.

keyCharacters.name: The Kenites
keyCharacters.description: A group allied with Israel who are spared from destruction because of their kindness to Israel during the Exodus.

definitions.definition: A nomadic tribe hostile to Israel, remembered for attacking Israel after the Exodus, and subject to divine judgment.
The act of following God's commands fully and faithfully, valued above ritual sacrifices.
An archaic term meaning to regret or feel sorrow, here describing God's regret over Saul's failure.
Sacrificial offerings made to God, symbolizing devotion but insufficient without obedience.

outline.heading: God’s Command to Saul Regarding Amalek
outline.description: Samuel delivers God's command to Saul to utterly destroy the Amalekites, recalling their past hostility to Israel. Saul gathers his army and prepares for battle, demonstrating the seriousness of the divine mandate.

outline.heading: Saul’s Partial Obedience and Disobedience
outline.description: Saul spares King Agag and the best livestock, disobeying God's command to destroy everything. He protects the Kenites due to their kindness, but overall fails to carry out the complete judgment.

outline.heading: God’s Regret and Samuel’s Mourning
outline.description: God expresses regret for making Saul king because of his disobedience. Samuel mourns and prays all night, showing the gravity of Saul’s failure.

outline.heading: Samuel Confronts Saul
outline.description: Samuel confronts Saul about his disobedience. Saul attempts to justify his actions by claiming the spared livestock were for sacrifice, but Samuel exposes his rebellion.

outline.heading: The Consequences of Disobedience
outline.description: Samuel teaches that obedience is better than sacrifice and declares Saul rejected by God as king. Saul admits his sin but is ultimately rejected. Samuel executes Agag, and the chapter closes with Samuel mourning Saul’s downfall.

application: Obedience to God's commands is paramount; partial obedience is disobedience and leads to serious consequences.
Trust God fully rather than fearing human approval, as Saul did when he spared the best livestock.
True worship pleases God only when it flows from a heart that obeys Him completely.
God’s judgment is just and certain; believers should heed His word promptly and fully.

keyVerses.text: And Samuel said, Hath the LORD as great delight in burnt offerings and sacrifices, as in obeying the voice of the LORD? Behold, to obey is better than sacrifice, and to hearken than the fat of rams.
keyVerses.significance: This verse emphasizes that obedience to God is more valuable than ritual sacrifices, underscoring the heart of true worship.

keyVerses.text: For rebellion is as the sin of witchcraft, and stubbornness is as iniquity and idolatry. Because thou hast rejected the word of the LORD, he hath also rejected thee from being king.
keyVerses.significance: It reveals the seriousness of rebellion against God, equating it with witchcraft and idolatry, and explains Saul’s rejection as king.

keyVerses.text: It repenteth me that I have set up Saul to be king: for he is turned back from following me, and hath not performed my commandments. And it grieved Samuel; and he cried unto the LORD all night.
keyVerses.significance: This verse shows God's sorrow over Saul’s failure and Samuel’s deep intercession, highlighting the gravity of disobedience.

keyVerses.text: And Samuel said unto him, The LORD hath rent the kingdom of Israel from thee this day, and hath given it to a neighbour of thine, that is better than thou.
keyVerses.significance: This verse marks the official rejection of Saul’s kingship and the transfer of God’s favor to a more obedient leader.
